front.title: The 'Imminent' Response Code for the Constrained Application Protocol (CoAP)

abstract.t: This document proposes a new CoAP response code, 2.06 Imminent. A CoAP server can use this response code to signal that it has accepted the request but has not yet started processing it or that processing the request will take longer than a client is typically willing to wait for a response. A 2.06 response can include status information and indicate a location where the result will become available.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Constrained Application Protocol (CoAP) is a request/response protocol not unlike HTTP. CoAP defines no upper bound for the time between a request and the resulting response. E.g., in CoAP over UDP, a server is expected to return an empty Acknowledgement to the client if it cannot provide a response right away, but there is no limit on when the server should return the Separate Response.

In particular in the case of requests with long processing times, a CoAP client faces the problem that it cannot easily determine how long it should wait for the response and whether the CoAP server is even still processing the request. Long processing times occur, for example, when requests need manual intervention to authorize their processing, or when they perform a long sequence of remote actions. An example is provided by the "possibly long" authorization request specified in EST-coaps.

This document proposes a new CoAP response code, 2.06 Imminent. The semantics of this response code are modelled after the HTTP 202 (Accepted) status code:
The 202 (Accepted) status code indicates that the request has been accepted for processing, but the processing has not been completed. The request might or might not eventually be acted upon, as it might be disallowed when processing actually takes place. [...] The representation sent with this response ought to describe the request's current status and point to (or embed) a status monitor that can provide the user with an estimate of when the request will be fulfilled.
The 2.06 (Imminent) response code is not meant for overload cases, which are better handled by the 5.03 (Service Unavailable) response code.

section.title: 2.06 Imminent
section.t: A 2.06 (Imminent) response in reply to a GET request indicates that the target resource exists but no representation of the resource is available yet. The Max-Age Option indicates after what time a client should retry its GET request to retrieve the representation. The client MAY observe the resource (see ) to be notified when the representation becomes available.

A 2.06 (Imminent) response in reply to a POST request indicates that the result of processing the request is not available yet, for example, because the server needs longer to process the request than a client is typically willing to wait for a response. The server MAY specify a location using the Location-* options where the result will become available. If the server does not specify a location, the result will become available at the target resource. To receive the result, the client MAY poll or observe the resource at the specified location with a GET request. The Max-Age Option indicates how long the client should wait before making the GET request.

A 2.06 (Imminent) response MAY contain a payload that represents the progress of processing the original request or any other status information. The content format of this representation is specified by the Content-Format Option.

A 2.06 (Imminent) response is cacheable, but cannot be validated. If it contains Location-* options, it invalidates any cached response for the resource at the specified location; otherwise, it invalidates any cached response for the target resource of the request.

As a consequence of being cacheable, a 2.06 (Imminent) response in reply to a POST request makes the POST method temporarily idempotent: until Max-Age expires, any POST request with the same cache-key -- be it from the same client or any another client -- yields the same 2.06 (Imminent) response. (This is the same behavior as for 4.xx and 5.xx error responses in reply to POST requests.)

section.title: Observing Resources
section.t: When a client registers to observe a resource for which no representation is available yet, the server MAY send one or more 2.06 (Imminent) notifications before sending the first 2.05 (Content) or 2.03 (Valid) notification. The possible resulting sequence of notifications is shown in .

Unless the server is not willing to add the client to the list of observers, each 2.06 (Imminent) notification includes an Observe Option with a sequence number as specified in . Otherwise, the registration request falls back to a normal GET request.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This section analyses the possible threats to the CoAP "imminent" response code extension. It is meant to inform protocol and application developers about the security limitations of the "imminent" response code as described in this document.

The "imminent" is subject to the same general security considerations as all CoAP methods as described in Section 11 of . Specifically, the security considerations for "imminent" are closest to those of the observe option ast stated in section 7 of , because the server stores additional state over an extended period.

The payloads defined in the present specification are secured following the CoAP recommendations for the existing methods as specified in section 9 of . When additional security techniques are standardized for CoAP (e.g., Object Security), these are then also available for securing this additional response code.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document adds the 2.06 (Imminent) response code to the "CoAP Response Codes" registry.
